items.prompt: Define the nature-nurture debate in psychology.
keyPoints: Nature refers to genetic or hereditary influences.
Nurture refers to environmental influences.
The debate concerns the relative contribution of genes and environment to human behavior.

markingCriteria.full: Includes all key points with accurate detail
markingCriteria.partial: Includes 1-2 key points or lacks detail

items.prompt: What is the interactionist approach in the nature-nurture debate?
keyPoints: Interactionist approach suggests that nature and nurture interact to influence behavior.
Genes and environment are seen as interdependent.
Example: Diathesis-stress model where genetic vulnerability interacts with environmental stressors.

markingCriteria.full: Includes all key points with accurate detail
markingCriteria.partial: Includes 1-2 key points or lacks detail

items.prompt: What are some research methods used to study the nature-nurture debate?
keyPoints: Twin studies: Compare concordance rates between MZ and DZ twins.
Adoption studies: Examine similarities between adopted children and their biological vs. adoptive parents.
Family studies: Look at the prevalence of traits within families.

markingCriteria.full: Includes all key points with accurate detail
markingCriteria.partial: Includes 1-2 key points or lacks detail

items.prompt: A child demonstrates a high level of intelligence and excels in school. Apply the nature-nurture debate to explain this behavior.
keyPoints: Nature: Inherited intelligence from parents.
Nurture: High-quality education and stimulating environment.
Interaction: Genetic predisposition enhanced by nurturing environment.

markingCriteria.full: Applies both nature and nurture perspectives accurately with examples
markingCriteria.partial: Applies either nature or nurture with limited examples

items.prompt: Consider a scenario where an individual develops a phobia after a traumatic event. Use the nature-nurture debate to explain this.
keyPoints: Nature: Genetic predisposition to anxiety or phobias.
Nurture: Traumatic event as environmental trigger.
Interaction: Genetic vulnerability activated by environmental trigger.

markingCriteria.full: Applies both nature and nurture perspectives accurately with examples
markingCriteria.partial: Applies either nature or nurture with limited examples

items.prompt: A person is highly skilled at playing the piano. Apply the nature-nurture debate to explain this ability.
keyPoints: Nature: Inherited musical talent or abilities.
Nurture: Extensive practice and musical training.
Interaction: Genetic predisposition supported by nurture.

markingCriteria.full: Applies both nature and nurture perspectives accurately with examples
markingCriteria.partial: Applies either nature or nurture with limited examples

items.prompt: Evaluate the role of twin studies in understanding the nature-nurture debate.
keyPoints: Point: Twin studies provide valuable data on genetic vs. environmental influences.
Evidence: Comparison of concordance rates between MZ and DZ twins.
Elaboration: High concordance in MZ twins suggests genetic influence.
Limitation: Twins often share the same environment, confounding results.

markingCriteria.full: Includes all key points with analysis and evidence
markingCriteria.partial: Includes some key points but lacks depth or evidence

items.prompt: Discuss the limitations of adoption studies in the nature-nurture debate.
keyPoints: Point: Adoption studies aim to separate genetic and environmental influences.
Evidence: Compare traits between adopted children and biological vs. adoptive parents.
Elaboration: Assumes adoption environments are different from biological ones.
Limitation: Adoption agencies often place children in environments similar to their biological families.

markingCriteria.full: Includes all key points with analysis and evidence
markingCriteria.partial: Includes some key points but lacks depth or evidence

items.prompt: Evaluate the interactionist approach in the nature-nurture debate.
keyPoints: Point: Interactionist approach considers both genetic and environmental factors.
Evidence: Diathesis-stress model as an example.
Elaboration: Offers a more comprehensive understanding than either perspective alone.
Limitation: Difficult to quantify the extent of interaction between genes and environment.

markingCriteria.full: Includes all key points with analysis and evidence
markingCriteria.partial: Includes some key points but lacks depth or evidence
